questions.text: A 14-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of an abdominal bulge that has become more noticeable as he began to walk 2 weeks ago. The bulge increases on crying and disappears when he is lying down. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section. He has met all developmental milestones. He has been breastfed since birth. He appears healthy and active. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a nontender, 1-cm midabdominal mass that is easily reducible. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgical repair would be indicated in the case of bowel strangulation, and an open repair would only be indicated if there was significant damage to a bowel that would not be feasible to repair laparoscopically. Because this patient has no signs of peritonitis (significant pain, rebound, or guarding) that would indicate possible strangulation, emergency open repair is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Elective surgical repair is not indicated for an asymptomatic, congenital umbilical hernia in an infant. If the abdominal wall defect does not close with time or leads to any complications, elective surgery may be indicated.

C) CORRECT:

The vast majority of congenital umbilical hernias close spontaneously by age 5. Because the patient is asymptomatic and the hernia is small, the most appropriate management at this time is reassurance and observation. The risk of complications (e.g., incarceration, strangulation) is low in comparison to other types of hernias.

If the patient develops features of bowel obstruction, such as constipation, vomiting, or incessant crying, or if the hernia does not decrease with time, surgical repair may be indicated.
Image Description:

Anterior abdominal wall of a newborn

There is a mass ∼2 cm in diameter protruding through the umbilical orifice.

This is the typical appearance of a congenital umbilical hernia, which characteristically increases in size on crying or coughing.

D) INCORRECT:

Umbilical hernias are diagnosed by clinical evaluation. An abdominal ultrasound would be performed to evaluate complications, but the absence of hernia tenderness, erythema, pain, nausea, vomiting, or peritonitis makes incarceration or strangulation of the hernia unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair of a congenital umbilical hernia is indicated in cases of strangulation, incarceration, or a large abdominal wall defect (> 1.5 cm), but the defect in this patient is 1 cm and reducible.

F) INCORRECT:

A congenital abdominal hernia can be diagnosed by clinical evaluation alone without exposing the child to unnecessary radiation.
questions.hint: The patient's physical examination is most consistent with a congenital umbilical hernia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of mild left-sided abdominal pain when lifting heavy objects that has developed over the past 6 months. He has had a weight loss of 41 kg (90 lb) in the past year. Physical examination shows a soft bulge inferior and lateral to the navel on the left. A CT scan of the abdomen of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following muscles is located directly medial to the pathology seen on the CT scan?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The psoas major is not a muscle of the anterior abdominal wall and would not be located medial to this defect. The psoas major originates from the lumbar vertebra and pelvic brim and inserts into the lesser trochanter of the femur.

B) INCORRECT:

The internal oblique aponeurosis is part of the linea semilunaris. This muscle originates laterally from the iliac crest and lumbar fascia and continues medially to the linea semilunaris. In the case of a Spigelian hernia, the hernia sac protrudes directly through the internal oblique aponeurosis, which means the internal oblique muscle would be lateral to the hernia.

C) INCORRECT:

The external oblique muscle lies superficial and lateral to the defect on this patient's CT scan. The medial aponeurosis of this muscle contributes to the most superficial part of the linea semilunaris and helps to reinforce the anterior portion of the rectus sheath. The structure medial to the hernia is a different muscle.

D) CORRECT:

The rectus abdominis muscle lies directly medial to the hernia sac on this CT scan. Spigelian hernias occur through defects in the linea semilunaris of the anterior abdominal wall. The linea semilunaris is a curved, vertical line at the lateral edge of each rectus abdominis muscle that is composed of the aponeurotic fibers of the internal oblique muscle as they merge with the rectus sheath. Spigelian hernias are therefore bounded medially by the rectus abdominis. These hernias are occasionally palpable as a subcutaneous bulge. However, they are most commonly intraperitoneal and may not be evident on examination. Because the fascial defects are typically small, there is a high risk of bowel strangulation; surgical repair is therefore indicated.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anterior abdominal wall of a female patient

An ill-defined swelling is visible just lateral to the left rectus abdominis muscle (i.e., along the semilunar line). Examination of the mass showed a positive cough impulse.

This is the typical appearance of a Spigelian hernia, an uncommon ventral hernia.

E) INCORRECT:

The transverse abdominal muscle is the deepest of the anterior abdominal wall muscles. It contributes fibers to the most posterior part of the linea semilunaris, which is deep to the internal oblique. The defect seen in this patient would occur through the aponeurotic fibers of the transverse abdominal muscles, which means that the transverse abdominal muscles would not be medial to the defect.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a left-sided Spigelian hernia. Rapid weight loss is a risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: A 22-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, lethargy, and an abdominal protrusion. The child was delivered at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. The patient is at the 25th percentile for height, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, pale facies, and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a protruding mass at the abdominal midline. The skin covering the protrusion appears normal. When the newborn cries during the examination, the mass enlarges but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the abdominal protrusion?

choices.text: Failed convergence of the lateral embryologic folds
Failed obliteration of the vitelline duct
Congenital weakness of the linea alba
Persistence of a patent processus vaginalis
Failed spontaneous closure of the umbilical ring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed convergence of the lateral embryologic folds leads to abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele, which can manifest as a protruding abdominal mass near or in the midline, as seen here. However, in gastroschisis, the intestines herniate uncovered by skin or peritoneum and in omphalocele, the intestines herniate through the umbilical ring covered only by peritoneum. This patient's skin-covered abdominal protrusion has a different cause.
Image Description:

Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.

Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.

Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.

Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

B) INCORRECT:

Complete failure of the vitelline duct to obliterate during the 7th week of development causes a vitelline fistula; partial failure results in Meckel diverticulum. A vitelline fistula causes meconium discharge through the umbilicus. A Meckel diverticulum is asymptomatic in most cases and sometimes manifests with diverticulitis or painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Neither of these conditions would manifest with an abdominal protrusion.
Image Description:

The Meckel diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct. The omphalomesenteric duct connects the yolk sac to the alimentary tract in the embryo (left image). The duct is normally obliterated by the 6th week of intrauterine life. However, incomplete obliteration leads to the development of a diverticulum located approx. 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve (right image). The Meckel diverticulum is often connected to the navel via a fibrous cord, which is the obliterated part of the omphalomesenteric duct (middle image).

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital weakness of the linea alba is the cause of an epigastric hernia, which occurs in the abdominal midline (between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus) and can manifest with an abdominal protrusion that enlarges with an increase in abdominal pressure (e.g., during crying), as seen here. However, epigastric hernias typically manifest during adulthood, not during the neonatal period. The abdominal protrusion in this patient has a different cause.
Image Description:

Herniation of intraabdominal contents through the linea alba, between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus.

D) INCORRECT:

The persistence of a patent processus vaginalis is the cause of an indirect inguinal hernia, which manifests as a mass that enlarges with increases in abdominal pressure (e.g., during crying), as seen here. However, an indirect inguinal hernia would manifest in the groin, not the abdominal midline.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

E) CORRECT:

Failure of the umbilical ring to close during fetal development causes congenital umbilical hernia. The midgut develops outside the abdominal cavity until the second trimester, when it physiologically herniates back into the abdomen. If the umbilical ring fails to close or the fascia in this region is underdeveloped, abdominal content may bulge through the umbilicus. Umbilical hernias are more common in children with chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, Edwards syndrome) or congenital hypothyroidism, as seen here. Most congenital umbilical hernias resolve spontaneously by 5 years of age.
Image Description:

Anterior abdominal wall of a newborn

There is a mass ∼2 cm in diameter protruding through the umbilical orifice.

This is the typical appearance of a congenital umbilical hernia, which characteristically increases in size on crying or coughing.
questions.hint: This patient has features consistent with congenital hypothyroidism (poor feeding, lethargy, prolonged newborn jaundice, pale facies, increased head circumference, abdominal distention, and macroglossia). His midline abdominal protrusion is a congenital umbilical hernia, a common feature of congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of worsening abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, propranolol, and apixaban. Her temperature is 37.1ºC (98.8ºF), pulse is 95/min and irregular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 99/71 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, tender mass in the left lower quadrant near the midline. The mass does not expand upon coughing. Active straight leg raise in the supine position increases pain and prominence of the mass but causes no change in the location of the mass. Palpation of the other abdominal quadrants shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?

choices.text: Accumulation of blood within the rectus sheath
Occlusion of a mesenteric blood vessel

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Accumulation of blood within the rectus sheath causes a rectus sheath hematoma (RSH). This condition typically results from a sudden, forceful contraction of the rectus abdominis muscle (RAM) causing a tear in an epigastric artery or in the RAM itself. RSH manifests with acute abdominal pain and a tender mass that is located within the abdominal wall and does not cross the midline. Carnett sign and Fothergill sign, both seen here, are characteristic of this condition. If the RSH is large enough, the patient may develop hypovolemia, signs that mimic peritonitis (e.g., abdominal guarding), and abdominal compartment syndrome. A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT is used to confirm the diagnosis of RSH. Management includes treating the underlying cause (e.g., treatment of severe hypertension, reversal of anticoagulation) and providing hemodynamic support as needed. Selective arterial embolization and surgery are reserved for severe cases (e.g., refractory hypovolemia, abdominal compartment syndrome).
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with acute left anterior abdominal pain

There is marked asymmetry in size of the right and left rectus muscles. The enlarged left rectus muscle (green overlay) is heterogeneous, with low and high attenuation components. High attenuation (hatched green overlay) represents a site of contrast-enhanced blood from acute hemorrhage.

RRM: right rectus muscle

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured ovarian cyst can manifest with acute abdominal pain and a tender, palpable abdominal mass in the left lower quadrant if the ruptured cyst has not collapsed completely. However, an ovarian cyst is an intraabdominal mass and would, therefore, become less prominent with maneuvers that tense the abdominal musculature. Furthermore, a ruptured ovarian cyst is more common in women of reproductive age. Patients may also present with vaginal bleeding and peritoneal signs, none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal and inguinal hernias can result in the incarceration of bowel contents (incarcerated hernia). A Spigelian hernia can manifest as a mass in the left lower quadrant and a hernia can become more prominent with maneuvers that tense the abdominal wall (as a result of increased intraabdominal pressure). However, incarcerated hernias are usually not tender and most commonly manifest with an expansile cough impulse. Acute abdominal pain, tenderness of the hernia, and an absent cough impulse can occur in an obstructed or strangulated hernia but in these cases, the patient would have features of bowel obstruction (e.g., absent bowel sounds).

D) INCORRECT:

Acute occlusion of a mesenteric blood vessel, i.e., acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI), manifests with acute abdominal pain. Furthermore, atrial fibrillation, which this patient has, is an important risk factor for AMI. However, a palpable mass is not an expected finding in this condition. Abdominal examination is typically unremarkable in the early stages of AMI but as bowel infarction develops, patients develop peritoneal signs (e.g., rigidity, guarding in all quadrants, decreased bowel sounds).

E) INCORRECT:

Acute diverticular inflammation (diverticulitis) can manifest with acute abdominal pain and a tender, palpable abdominal mass in the left lower quadrant (due to pericolic inflammation or a diverticular abscess). Diverticulosis, which predisposes to acute diverticulitis, is also common among elderly individuals. However, a palpable mass caused by either pericolic inflammation or a diverticular abscess is intraabdominal and would, therefore, become less prominent with maneuvers that tense the abdominal musculature.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute pancreatic inflammation (pancreatitis) manifests with acute abdominal pain. However, acute pancreatitis typically causes tenderness in the epigastric region rather than the left lower quadrant. Although pancreatic abscesses or pseudocysts are complications of acute pancreatitis that can manifest as a palpable abdominal mass, these occur days to weeks after an episode of acute pancreatitis and are located in the epigastrium. Moreover, both pancreatic abscesses and pseudocysts are intraabdominal masses and would, therefore, become less prominent with maneuvers that tense the abdominal musculature.
questions.hint: Risk factors for this patient's condition include anticoagulant therapy, advanced age, and hypertension, all of which are seen here. Other risk factors include pregnancy, blunt trauma, conditions associated with severe coughing (e.g., COPD), or straining during defecation or micturition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. The pain is located around the umbilicus and she describes it as an 8 out of 10 in intensity. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Her only medication is a multivitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 127/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, soft, irreducible, umbilical mass. There is no warmth or erythema around the mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an umbilical hernia with no evidence of mechanical bowel obstruction or strangulation. A single dose of fentanyl is administered. Twenty minutes later, the hernia is manually reduced and the pain has resolved. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe analgesics and a hernia truss

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hernia truss is used to externally compress a hernia after complete reduction. It can be considered for the treatment of inguinal hernias in men. This woman, however, has an umbilical hernia, for which a truss is not indicated. Prescribing analgesics is also not indicated because her pain resolved after manual reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

An emergency open surgical repair is indicated for all patients with an acutely complicated umbilical hernia (e.g., strangulation, bowel obstruction, perforation), which manifests with diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, guarding, and rebound tenderness. This patient presents with a symptomatic incarcerated hernia without signs of strangulation or bowel obstruction on her abdominal CT scan. Because her umbilical hernia is reducible following sufficient analgesics, emergency surgical repair is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of empiric antibiotic therapy would be appropriate if this patient had a strangulated or perforated umbilical hernia. However, she has no evidence of bowel obstruction, strangulation, or perforation on physical examination or on abdominal CT scan. Therefore, the use of antibiotics is not indicated at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with very small and asymptomatic umbilical hernias can be discharged and observed without further intervention, especially if the patient does not want to undergo surgery. Because this patient presented with a symptomatic, incarcerated umbilical hernia, further management is necessary to prevent recurrence and future complications (e.g., strangulation, bowel obstruction, perforation).

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a symptomatic, incarcerated umbilical hernia, which is more commonly seen in women and is usually an acquired condition that results from increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., due to pregnancy). Although most reducible hernias manifest as an asymptomatic, nontender mass, they can become symptomatic, especially if the fascial defect has a narrow neck, as is the case in umbilical hernias. This patient has no evidence of acute complications on physical examination (e.g., warmth, erythema, guarding) or from the abdominal CT scan (e.g., strangulation, bowel obstruction, perforation), and her umbilical hernia is reducible following sufficient analgesics. Therefore, she does not require emergency surgical repair. Because of the increased risk of recurrence and associated complications, all patients with reducible or incarcerated umbilical hernias should undergo elective ambulatory surgical repair.
questions.hint: The fascial defect in umbilical hernias is often small, which increases the risk of complications (e.g., incarceration, strangulation, bowel obstruction).

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with 24 hours of progressive, crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and multiple episodes of vomiting. She has not passed stool or flatus in 12 hours. Examination shows abdominal distension. A small bulge is noted in the right groin below the inguinal ligament. The skin overlying the bulge appears normal, and a cough impulse is absent (see report).


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Temperature
37°C


Abdominal radiographs: Multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel; no air in the colon
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation is indicative of an obstructed femoral hernia. The painful bulge below the inguinal ligament aligns with the typical location of a femoral hernia, which is more common in older women due to a wider femoral canal. Symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and absence of flatus or stool suggest bowel entrapment, leading to mechanical small bowel obstruction. Radiographic findings of multiple air-fluid levels support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: An obstructed hernia manifests with features of bowel obstruction and is characterized by the inability of bowel contents to pass through the herniated segment.

B) INCORRECT:

Sigmoid volvulus typically causes large bowel obstruction, with imaging showing a distended colon and 'coffee-bean' sign. The radiographs here show multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel with no air in the colon. Moreover, sigmoid volvulus does not cause an externalized mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Indirect inguinal hernias protrude through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and the hernial sac passes above the inguinal ligament. These hernias are common in infants and older men. Moreover, the skin overlying a strangulated hernia is typically warm and erythematous.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the Hesselbach triangle and are located above the inguinal ligament, unlike the bulge described below the inguinal ligament in this patient. They are more common in older men, making this diagnosis less likely in an elderly woman.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a painful bulge in his left groin that he noticed two days ago. The pain has worsened, and he reports nausea and vomiting. He has a history of chronic cough and constipation. Examination shows erythematous skin over the bulge, which is painful to palpation. Abdominal auscultation reveals tympanic sounds with diffuse tenderness but no rebound (see lab result).


Heart rate
105/min


Blood pressure
145/90 mm Hg


Temperature
38.3°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small bowel obstruction due to adhesions

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient presents with a painful groin bulge, erythematous skin, fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis, indicating systemic inflammation and compromised blood flow to the entrapped bowel. These findings suggest a strangulated hernia. In an indirect inguinal hernia, the bowel herniates through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels due to a patent processus vaginalis. Chronic cough and constipation increase intra-abdominal pressure, predisposing to hernia formation and complications. The gastrointestinal symptoms and localized inflammatory signs align with a strangulated indirect inguinal hernia.

Key learning point: A strangulated hernia is characterized by compromised blood supply to the herniated tissue, leading to ischemia, and is indicated by symptoms such as pain, tenderness, skin discoloration, and signs of bowel obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

A reducible hernia can be manipulated back into the abdominal cavity without significant pain or systemic symptoms. The patient's marked tenderness, erythema, fever, and elevated white blood cell count are not typical of a reducible hernia. Additionally, femoral hernias are less common in males, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A direct inguinal hernia results from acquired weakness in the transversalis fascia within Hesselbach’s triangle, creating a wider defect. This typically allows herniated contents to move freely, reducing the risk of incarceration and strangulation. The systemic inflammation and gastrointestinal obstruction signs are more characteristic of a hernia with a narrower neck, making an incarcerated direct inguinal hernia less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction (SBO) due to adhesions is common in patients with a history of abdominal surgery or peritonitis, leading to fibrous bands causing obstruction. The absence of surgical history and the presence of a painful groin bulge with erythema suggest a hernia complication rather than adhesive SBO. Chronic cough and constipation further support hernia development.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of a bulge at the umbilicus present since birth. The mother notes it becomes more noticeable when he cries or coughs. The child is otherwise healthy. Examination shows a 1 cm diameter bulge at the umbilicus that is easily reducible, nontender, and has normal overlying skin.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend daily use of abdominal binder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal binders are used in adults or postoperative settings but are not necessary for pediatric umbilical hernias. A binder may cause discomfort or skin irritation without aiding closure.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair is considered if complications (e.g., incarceration, strangulation) arise, if a congenital umbilical hernia fails to close spontaneously, and in patients with acquired umbilical hernias. In an 18-month-old child with a small, easily reducible, congenital umbilical hernia, a different step is appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Umbilical hernias in infants result from incomplete closure of the umbilical ring and typically present as a reducible bulge that becomes more pronounced with increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., crying, coughing). 10–20% of infants born at term have a congenital umbilical hernia. Most close spontaneously by age 3–5 years. The small size (< 2 cm), reducible and nontender nature, and increased prominence with increased intra-abdominal pressure indicate a low risk of complications (e.g., incarceration, strangulation). Continued observation with routine follow-up is appropriate to ensure normal resolution. Surgical intervention is only considered if the hernia is large, persists beyond the typical age, or shows signs of complications.

Key learning point: Most umbilical hernias in infants resolve spontaneously by age 3 to 5 years, and observation is the appropriate management unless the hernia is large, symptomatic, or persistent.

D) INCORRECT:

This child's hernia is small, reducible, and becomes more pronounced with an increase in intra-abdominal pressure, typical of an uncomplicated congenital umbilical hernia. Physical examination is diagnostic, and imaging is unnecessary unless there is diagnostic uncertainty (e.g., for ambiguous abdominal masses, complex hernias) or a complication (e.g., incarceration, strangulation) is suspected.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman presents with sudden severe left-sided abdominal pain after an intense coughing episode. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and is on long-term anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation. Examination reveals a tender, firm swelling lateral to the midline that remains unchanged with coughing or changes in posture. She is hemodynamically stable but appears very uncomfortable. 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spigelian hernias occur through the Spigelian fascia and are reducible, changing size with intra-abdominal pressure variations. The firm swelling in this patient remains unchanged with coughing, inconsistent with a hernia.

B) INCORRECT:

Incisional hernias occur at previous surgical sites and show a positive cough impulse, becoming more prominent with increased intra-abdominal pressure. This patient has no surgical history or scars, and the swelling remains unchanged with coughing.

C) INCORRECT:

Epigastric hernias occur between the xiphoid process and umbilicus and typically show a positive cough impulse, increasing in size with coughing. The swelling in this patient is lateral to the midline and unchanged with coughing, inconsistent with a hernia.

D) CORRECT:

Rectus sheath hematoma results from bleeding into the rectus abdominis muscle, often triggered by increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as intense coughing. This patient, with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and on anticoagulation, is predisposed to vessel rupture within the rectus sheath. The condition presents with acute, localized abdominal pain and a palpable mass that remains unchanged with posture or Valsalva maneuvers, unlike hernias. The fixed nature of the mass differentiates it from hernias, which typically vary with intra-abdominal pressure.

Key learning point: A rectus sheath hematoma presents as a painful abdominal swelling that persists with muscle contraction and has a negative cough impulse, often following trauma or strain.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with acute left anterior abdominal pain

There is marked asymmetry in size of the right and left rectus muscles. The enlarged left rectus muscle (green overlay) is heterogeneous, with low and high attenuation components. High attenuation (hatched green overlay) represents a site of contrast-enhanced blood from acute hemorrhage.

RRM: right rectus muscle

This is the typical appearance of a congenital umbilical hernia, which characteristically increases in size on crying or coughing.

D) INCORRECT:

Umbilical hernias are diagnosed by clinical evaluation. An abdominal ultrasound would be performed to evaluate complications, but the absence of hernia tenderness, erythema, pain, nausea, vomiting, or peritonitis makes incarceration or strangulation of the hernia unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Elective surgical repair is not indicated for an asymptomatic, congenital umbilical hernia in an infant. If the abdominal wall defect does not close with time or leads to any complications, elective surgery may be indicated.
questions.hint: The patient's physical examination is most consistent with a congenital umbilical hernia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of umbilical hernia repair 3 years ago presents with a 12-hour history of crampy abdominal pain and a firm mass at her previous surgical site. She reports intermittent nausea but denies fever. The mass has been present for 6 months but was previously soft and reducible. On examination, vital signs are normal except for mild tachycardia. The mass is firm, nontender, and cannot be reduced despite positioning and gentle pressure. A cough impulse is present. She has not had a bowel movement in 8 hours but continues to pass flatus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Attempt manual reduction with procedural sedation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV antibiotics are reserved for patients with clear signs of infection or sepsis. In the absence of fever or systemic symptoms, antibiotics do not address the urgent issue indicated by this patient’s acute presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging may provide additional detail but should not delay urgent evaluation when clinical signs suggest incarceration with possible obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction carries risks and is typically not performed before surgical evaluation, especially when there are symptoms consistent with bowel obstruction.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has an acutely irreducible incisional hernia with symptoms that suggest bowel obstruction (crampy pain, no bowel movement). The presence of a cough impulse and absence of fever or skin changes suggests incarceration without strangulation. Urgent surgical consultation is required for potential manual reduction or surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is inappropriate when acute changes in hernia characteristics and obstructive symptoms are present, as these require prompt assessment.

An 80-year-old man presents with sudden onset of intense right lower abdominal pain after an episode of severe coughing. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin therapy. Examination reveals localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound tenderness, and a distinct, slightly tender, palpable mass in the abdominal wall (see lab results and report).

CT imaging: Localized hematoma within the right rectus sheath
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Conservative management with rest and analgesics
Drainage of the hematoma under ultrasound guidance

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rectus sheath hematomas occur due to bleeding into the rectus muscle sheath, often exacerbated by anticoagulation. The CT imaging confirms a localized hematoma, and the patient is hemodynamically stable despite a high international normalized ratio (INR). Conservative management, including rest, analgesia, and observation, is appropriate as many hematomas resolve without invasive intervention. Monitoring for changes and adjusting anticoagulation therapy are essential components of this approach.

Key learning point: In stable patients with a rectus sheath hematoma, conservative management with rest and analgesia is often appropriate, especially when the patient is on anticoagulation therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent laparotomy is indicated for diffuse intra-abdominal hemorrhage or peritonitis. The CT imaging shows a localized rectus sheath hematoma, and the patient is hemodynamically stable, making surgical exploration unnecessary. The elevated INR and hemoglobin drop are consistent with warfarin-associated bleeding, not requiring immediate surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate warfarin reversal is reserved for life-threatening hemorrhage or rapid bleeding with hemodynamic instability. This patient has a localized rectus sheath hematoma with stable vital signs. Abrupt anticoagulation reversal in atrial fibrillation patients can increase thromboembolic risk, making conservative management more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided drainage is considered for fluid collections with infection or significant mass effect. This patient has a contained rectus sheath hematoma without hemodynamic compromise. The high INR increases bleeding risk with invasive procedures, favoring noninvasive management.
